name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can explain why radioactive decay is described as random
items.what: It is impossible to predict when any individual nucleus will decay. However, with large numbers of nuclei, we can statistically predict the overall decay rate using the half-life concept.
items.why: Understanding the random nature of decay explains why we use statistical measures like half-life rather than trying to predict individual decay events.
items.example: One gram of uranium-238 contains 2.6 √ó 10¬≤¬π atoms. While we cannot predict which specific atom will decay next, we can predict that half will decay over 4.5 billion years.

items.title: I can define half-life and explain what it represents
items.what: Half-life (t¬Ω) is the time taken for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay. It is constant for each isotope and unaffected by temperature, pressure, or chemical environment.
items.why: Half-life is a fundamental property of each radioisotope that determines its applications, from short half-lives for medical tracers to long half-lives for geological dating.
items.example: Technetium-99m has a half-life of 6.0 hours, meaning after 6 hours, only half the original technetium-99m remains. After 12 hours, only one-quarter remains.

items.why: This calculation is essential for determining how long radioactive materials remain dangerous, planning medical treatments, and dating ancient objects.
items.example: If you start with 100 g of a substance with a 10-day half-life, after 30 days (3 half-lives): N = 100 √ó (¬Ω)¬≥ = 100 √ó 0.125 = 12.5 g remaining.

items.title: I can define and calculate the activity of a radioactive source
items.what: Activity is the number of nuclear decays per second, measured in becquerels (Bq), where 1 Bq = 1 decay per second. Activity decreases as the radioactive material decays, following the same half-life relationship.
items.why: Activity measures the current strength of a radioactive source, which determines its usefulness for applications and its radiation hazard level.
items.example: A cobalt-60 source has an initial activity of 440 TBq. After one half-life (5.27 years), its activity will be 220 TBq. After two half-lives, it will be 110 TBq.

items.why: This skill is used in radiocarbon dating and other techniques to determine the age of samples by measuring how much radioactive material remains.
items.example: A bone sample contains ¬º of its original carbon-14. Since ¬º = (¬Ω)¬≤, two half-lives have elapsed. With carbon-14's half-life of 5730 years, the bone is about 11,460 years old.

items.title: I can explain why different radioisotopes are chosen for different applications
items.what: The half-life of a radioisotope determines its suitability for different uses. Medical tracers need short half-lives (hours to days), while smoke detectors need long half-lives (centuries).
items.why: Choosing the right half-life ensures the radioisotope remains useful for its intended purpose while minimising unnecessary radiation exposure.
items.example: Technetium-99m (6 hours) is ideal for medical scans as it decays quickly after imaging. Americium-241 (460 years) is used in smoke detectors so they never need isotope replacement.
